N20070714-0010

I recently added some layout tests for UA forms. Two of them fail on MacOS (carbon). I haven't yet been able to log onto a Mac to check this out to determine whether the test is making an invalid assumption for the Mac. The tests and failures are:

testTableWrapLayoutWrappingLabels

Label is too wide for layout 

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Label is too wide for layout 
at org.eclipse.ua.tests.forms.layout.TestTableWrapLayout.testTableWrapLayoutWrappingLabels(TestTableWrapLayout.java:77)

testTableWrapLayoutAlignment

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
at org.eclipse.ua.tests.forms.layout.TestTableWrapLayout.testTableWrapLayoutAlignment(TestTableWrapLayout.java:172)
at org.eclipse.test.EclipseTestRunner.run(EclipseTestRunner.java:354)
at org.eclipse.test.EclipseTestRunner.run(EclipseTestRunner.java:206)

The problem with testTableWrapLayoutWrappingLabels is that on mac the labels have a width of 103 which is larger than the shell size. On Windows they have a width of 88. I'm still not sure the exact reason for this, but I noticed that upon entry to TableWrapLayout.layout() the "inner" composite reports the width of its client area as 98 on Windows and 113 on Mac. 98 is reasonable as the inner composite is given the entire area of the shell minus 2 pixels. Why the composite thinks it has more real estate than the shell on Mac I still haven't figured out.

In both cases the width reported by the labels is client area width minus 10, so the problem seems to stem from the incorrect client area.

If the shell is actually opened before the test completes and you look at it by debugging through the code, you can see that the text is displayed in full and properly wrapped in both cases. I'm also unsure why the inaccurate width is not affecting the display of the label on Mac.

traces.message: Label is too wide for layout
